title: Visual Acuity Testing (Snellen Chart)
description: Assesses binocular and monocular visual acuity using standardized Snellen optotypes. This test evaluates the clarity of vision by determining the smallest line of letters a patient can accurately read on a standardized chart at a specific distance. Visual acuity testing is a fundamental component of ophthalmologic and neurologic examinations, particularly for cranial nerve II (optic nerve) assessment.

parameters.name: lowest_line_read
parameters.description: The lowest (smallest) line that the patient can read correctly on the Snellen chart

parameters.name: testing_distance
parameters.description: Distance at which the test was performed

parameters.name: corrective_lenses
parameters.description: Whether the patient was wearing corrective lenses during testing

result.name: visual_acuity
result.description: Visual acuity measurement in standard notation

ranges.interpretation: Visual acuity of 20/20 represents normal vision. The patient can read letters at 20 feet that a person with normal vision can read at 20 feet. No further evaluation is typically needed unless other visual complaints are present.

Visual acuity between 20/25 and 20/40 indicates mild visual impairment. This may suggest need for corrective lenses or early eye disease. Ophthalmologic evaluation is recommended, particularly if this represents a change from baseline.

Visual acuity between 20/50 and 20/100 represents moderate visual impairment. This level of vision loss significantly impacts daily activities and requires ophthalmologic evaluation to determine the underlying cause and appropriate treatment.

ranges.description: Severe visual impairment approaching legal blindness
ranges.interpretation: Visual acuity between 20/125 and 20/200 represents severe visual impairment. Visual acuity of 20/200 or worse is considered legally blind in the United States. Urgent ophthalmologic evaluation is indicated.

Counting fingers (CF), hand motion (HM), light perception (LP), or no light perception (NLP) represent profound visual impairment. This requires immediate ophthalmologic evaluation to determine if the vision loss is reversible and to identify any treatable causes.

formula: Visual acuity = Testing distance / Distance at which normal eye can read the same line. Standard notation: 20/X where X is the denominator corresponding to the smallest line read correctly.
notes: Test each eye independently with the opposite eye covered
Ensure proper lighting and standardized testing distance
Visual acuity worse than 20/25 warrants professional ophthalmologic evaluation
Sudden changes in visual acuity require urgent evaluation
This test does not replace comprehensive eye examination
Mobile/smartphone testing should use 4-foot distance with maximum screen brightness
For patients over 40, presbyopia may affect near vision testing accuracy
If unable to read letters, test counting fingers, hand motion, light perception, and no light perception in sequence
Results should be documented as corrected or uncorrected visual acuity
Standard Snellen optotypes include letters C, D, E, F, L, O, P, T, and Z
